SECTION SEVEN
PROGRAM IDEAS FOR RADIO
It is commonly believed today that radio has
become the casualty of advancing technology in
modern communications. Certainly, we have heard
less and less about the importance of radio broad¬
casting capability in the past two decades. When
we think, or hear about mass communications today,
our thoughts automatically turn to television,
and somewhere, buried deep in our memories, we re¬
call something of radio.
In a very important sense this "second cousin" to
television broadcasting could prove a bonanza for
our programming needs in the war against poverty.
This is so for two very important reasons. First,
it is far less expensive and less complicated than
television. Second, there are many more operating
facilities available to us. The current comparative
figures reveal that there are two times the number
of existing educational radio stations as there are
educational television stations.
